2.text: “Yes, I know that it is so, but how can a mortal be righteous before God?

3.text: If one wished to contend with God, he could not answer Him one time out of a thousand.

4.text: God is wise in heart and mighty in strength. Who has resisted Him and prospered?

5.text: He moves mountains without their knowledge and overturns them in His anger.

6.text: He shakes the earth from its place, so that its foundations tremble.

7.text: He commands the sun not to shine; He seals off the stars.

8.text: He alone stretches out the heavens and treads on the waves of the sea.

9.text: He is the Maker of the Bear and Orion, of the Pleiades and the constellations of the south.

10.text: He does great things beyond searching out, and wonders without number.

11.text: Were He to pass by me, I would not see Him; were He to move, I would not recognize Him.

12.text: If He takes away, who can stop Him? Who dares to ask Him, ‘What are You doing?’

13.text: God does not restrain His anger; the helpers of Rahab cower beneath Him.

14.text: How then can I answer Him or choose my arguments against Him?

15.text: For even if I were right, I could not answer. I could only beg my Judge for mercy.

16.text: If I summoned Him and He answered me, I do not believe He would listen to my voice.

17.text: For He would crush me with a tempest and multiply my wounds without cause.

18.text: He does not let me catch my breath, but overwhelms me with bitterness.

19.text: If it is a matter of strength, He is indeed mighty! If it is a matter of justice, who can summon Him?

20.text: Even if I were righteous, my mouth would condemn me; if I were blameless, it would declare me guilty.

21.text: Though I am blameless, I have no concern for myself; I despise my own life.

22.text: It is all the same, and so I say, ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’

23.text: When the scourge brings sudden death, He mocks the despair of the innocent.

24.text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked; He blindfolds its judges. If it is not He, then who is it?

25.text: My days are swifter than a runner; they flee without seeing good.

26.text: They sweep by like boats of papyrus, like an eagle swooping down on its prey.

27.text: If I were to say, ‘I will forget my complaint and change my expression and smile,’

28.text: I would still dread all my sufferings; I know that You will not acquit me.

29.text: Since I am already found guilty, why should I labor in vain?

30.text: If I should wash myself with snow and cleanse my hands with lye,

31.text: then You would plunge me into the pit, and even my own clothes would despise me.

32.text: For He is not a man like me, that I can answer Him, that we can take each other to court.

33.text: Nor is there a mediator between us, to lay his hand upon us both.

34.text: Let Him remove His rod from me, so that His terror will no longer frighten me.

35.text: Then I would speak without fear of Him. But as it is, I am on my own.
